## Pacifist Key Bindings for GNU Screen

Many attempted [pacifist](/wiki/Pacifist "Pacifist") games end abruptly with accidentally [bump-killing](/wiki/Pacifist#Team_gecko "Pacifist") weak monsters, breaking pacifist conduct. One of the more extreme solutions to this problem is to use [GNU Screen](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GNU_Screen "wikipedia:GNU Screen") to remap the movement keys so they are all prefixed with [m](/wiki/M "M"). For example, pressing [k](/wiki/K "K") will actually send [m](/wiki/M "M")[k](/wiki/K "K") to the game. This eliminates the possibility of bump-killing (unless you're wielding [Stormbringer](/wiki/Stormbringer "Stormbringer"), but that would be a silly weapon choice for a pacifist), but can make other activities, like inventory management or choosing a direction to apply a [stethoscope](/wiki/Stethoscope "Stethoscope") or [key](/wiki/Key "Key"), somewhat annoying.

[Below](#RC_Files) is a set of three screen rc files that allow you to switch "pacifist mode" on and off while playing. After creating these files, you can start nethack with:

```
 screen -c ~/.screenrc-pacifist telnet nethack.alt.org
```

When you hit [F11](/index.php?title=F11\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "F11 (page does not exist)"), the key bindings are activated. Pressing [F12](/index.php?title=F12\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "F12 (page does not exist)") returns the bindings to normal. While the key bindings are activated, you can hit [ctrl](/wiki/Ctrl "Ctrl") + [t](/wiki/T "T") to send the next movement key as-is, without the [m](/wiki/M "M") prefix.

### RC Files

Simply create these three files and start nethack as above. The keys to turn pacifist mode on/off can be modified in \~/.screenrc-pacifist by replacing "F1" and "F2" with the keys of your choice. Type "k1" though "k9" to use the [F1](/index.php?title=F1\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "F1 (page does not exist)") through [F9](/index.php?title=F9\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "F9 (page does not exist)") keys, "k0" is [F10](/index.php?title=F10\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "F10 (page does not exist)"), and "F1" and "F2" are the [F11](/index.php?title=F11\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "F11 (page does not exist)") and [F12](/index.php?title=F12\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "F12 (page does not exist)") keys, respectively. You can also use, for example, [ctrl](/wiki/Ctrl "Ctrl") + [o](/wiki/O "O") by typing "^o" and omitting the "-k" argument.

#### \~/.screenrc-pacifist

```
# Hit F11 (not F1!) to enable pacifist key bindings
bindkey -k F1 source ~/.screenrc-pacifist-on
# Hit F12 (not F2!) to disable pacifist key bindings
bindkey -k F2 source ~/.screenrc-pacifist-off
```

#### \~/.screenrc-pacifist-on

```
# Enable pacifist key bindings:
# Defuse movement keys so they won't attack.
# Unfortunately, deactivates autopickup.
bindkey 'h' stuff 'mh'
bindkey 'y' stuff 'my'
bindkey 'k' stuff 'mk'
bindkey 'u' stuff 'mu'
bindkey 'l' stuff 'ml'
bindkey 'n' stuff 'mn'
bindkey 'j' stuff 'mj'
bindkey 'b' stuff 'mb'
# make control-t the unbound-prefix
bindkey "\024" mapdefault
wall "Pacifist mode activated!"
```

#### \~/.screenrc-pacifist-off

```
# Disable pacifist key bindings
bindkey 'h'
bindkey 'y'
bindkey 'k'
bindkey 'u'
bindkey 'l'
bindkey 'n'
bindkey 'j'
bindkey 'b'
bindkey "\024"
wall "Pacifist mode deactivated!"
```

One of the more extreme solutions to this problem is to use [[Wikipedia:GNU_Screen|GNU Screen]] to remap the movement keys so they are all prefixed with {{kbd|m}}.
